website_summaries.verdict: A highly detailed reference book created with professional and amateur herpetologists and naturalists in mind.
pros: Color illustrations and drawings show key details for better identification
Species accounts give key characteristics, compare with similar species, and describe habitats and ranges
This recent update also includes more than a hundred newly recognized or established non-native species
cons: Pictures are a bit small for identification purposes in order to keep it small enough to take into the field

customer_reviews.title: Excellent and a must for any herper interested in reptiles ...
customer_reviews.text: Excellent and a must for any herper interested in reptiles or amphibians of eastern North America. I can't love it yet because so much of the taxonomy is waiting for the DNA work-ups so taxonomists can define relationships better. The last change from Elaphe to Patherophis shook me up good. On the positive side this printing touches on the invasive species but there are many more of them than shown. Soon they will probably be enough to justify a Peterson Guide of their own. I would recommend it highly if you don't have an older copy. But if you have a recent printing skip this one and wait until they have the taxonomy straighten out.
customer_reviews.author: R. A. Hahn

customer_reviews.title: Nice and Updated
customer_reviews.text: This book received a long needed taxonomic update and moved the plates closer to the corresponding text. Species vs subspecies are also better delineated on the plates and in the text. A great number of introduced species, even some common ones, don't get illustrations on the plates, so you'd have to already know to look for them in the text. Some of the illustrations on the plates are a bit lacking or too small.
customer_reviews.author: Zach

customer_reviews.title: The essential classic: far superior to the Audubon guide
customer_reviews.text: This was my Bible growing up. I have the first and second editions (the latter with a personal signature by Roger Conant). Interesting to see the updated taxonomy and range maps. Essential for the young herpetologist in your life.
customer_reviews.author: Eric L. Peters

customer_reviews.title: Good purchase, but I had bad shipping
customer_reviews.text: The book itself is great, Peterson guides are a staple. I have my own copy and bought this one as a gift. Unfortunately the book was thrown in a too-large box with another item I ordered with no padding. My new book arrived with half the pages shoved out of the bottom box flap, creases throughout, and a well worn looking binding. As this is a gift I need this week I don't have time to return and request an undamaged copy. I'm pretty frustrated.
customer_reviews.author: Calli Wise

customer_reviews.title: Lovely field guide
customer_reviews.text: I am a wildlife major and this was required for 2 of my classes last semester. I usually sell books after the semester ends but decided to keep this one as I found it very helpful and think it would be useful in the future.
customer_reviews.author: Sara Westwood

customer_reviews.title: Great Guide
customer_reviews.text: Peterson makes great guidebooks, and this one is no exception. If you want to know for sure whether that's an alligator sitting in a flowerpot in your backyard, Peterson's the man to turn to. Nice read.
customer_reviews.author: Stephen Salniker

customer_reviews.title: Excellent rewrite of this guide
customer_reviews.text: Just returned from an extensive Herp trip to the Southeast and all 43 species of salamander that we found were covered in the guide. I had the only copy as we started the trip but a couple more were purchased on the road and delivered to our hotel. Very impressed but what they kept from the old version and​ the new information and plates added.
customer_reviews.author: David H. Small

customer_reviews.title: Educational. Great for the everyday or occasional herper!
customer_reviews.text: This is a gift for my 10 year old daughter, who like her mother, is a lover of all creatures and especially the reptiles and amphibians, so this is going to be a much loved educational field guide for her.
customer_reviews.author: Brianna Sortomme

customer_reviews.title: Thanks to Peterson I learned the snake that just crawled ...
customer_reviews.text: Thanks to Peterson I learned the snake that just crawled over my boot on the backwoods trail was not dangerous. Otherwise, I could have learned a different lesson. Thank goodness I had the Field Guide in hand.
customer_reviews.author: The Quain

customer_reviews.title: I've been using these guides on plants and animals for ...
customer_reviews.text: I've been using these guides on plants and animals for many years and find them invaluable. Many of the younger nature enthusiasts seem to use their electronic devices for identification, but I don't believe they can compare with this and similar series of field guides.
customer_reviews.author: Karl

customer_reviews.title: Great book! I could correctly identify the snakes on ...
customer_reviews.text: Great book! I could correctly identify the snakes on my farm as either safe or poisoning! Glad not to kill good snakes!
customer_reviews.author: Trish

customer_reviews.title: Amazingly informative and compact
customer_reviews.text: A very nice portable field guide to many different species.
customer_reviews.author: saisudha Nookathota

customer_reviews.title: Best herp field guide!
customer_reviews.text: Purchased for a Herpetology class. I already had an Audubon Society field guide, but this one was required for the class. I prefer this one now! It has a lot more IDing info and more species. I'll buy Peterson field guides from now on. As for purchase info, it arrived fast in perfect condition.
customer_reviews.author: taylor

customer_reviews.title: Love it
customer_reviews.text: This book arrived in perfect condition. I am very pleased with this field guide. I do wildlife photography and this will help me immensely with the description and habits of the little critters I'm taking pics of.
customer_reviews.author: Connie S. Platt

customer_reviews.title: Very pleased.
customer_reviews.text: Much thicker than I expected. Real photos and illustrations. Very pleased.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Five Stars
customer_reviews.text: Helpful book with information needed to identify reptiles and amphibians across USA.
customer_reviews.author: Alicia

customer_reviews.title: Gift
customer_reviews.text: I purchased this as a gift for my husband. He had enjoyed it.
customer_reviews.author: Gail Rogers

customer_reviews.title: Great book! It's very heavy and wonderful made quality
customer_reviews.text: Great book! It's very heavy and wonderful made quality. Definitely a very informative book and pretty easy to navigate.
customer_reviews.author: Happy Mommy :-)

customer_reviews.title: Very good and thorough
customer_reviews.text: Very good and thorough, as would be expected from Peterson guide! Print is very small, but I guess I just need to remember I'm getting old :)
customer_reviews.author: horsegal

customer_reviews.title: Very informative! I wish it had more photos though ...
customer_reviews.text: Very informative! I wish it had more photos though! I am a teacher and use it in my classroom, pictures are important
customer_reviews.author: Debbie Raggio

customer_reviews.title: The most up to date herp field guide available as ...
customer_reviews.text: The most up to date herp field guide available as of the time of this review. Lots of taxonomic changes.
customer_reviews.author: Zeke

customer_reviews.title: Best field guide ever.
customer_reviews.text: I love this book, it is the clearest, best written field guide I've ever worked with. Would highly recommend!
customer_reviews.author: Michaela McCoy

customer_reviews.title: Great
customer_reviews.text: It is just what I needed and it has great pictures to help with identifications.
customer_reviews.author: Rebecca Y.

customer_reviews.title: I believe this is the best field guide available covering the reptiles and amphibians of ...
customer_reviews.text: I believe this is the best field guide available covering the reptiles and amphibians of North America. Robert Powell carries on the incredible legacy of the late Roger Conant who was also a legend in the hematological community.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: but overall provides an excellent overview of reptiles and amphibians
customer_reviews.text: It's missing a few species I have come across in the field, but overall provides an excellent overview of reptiles and amphibians.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Excellent guide with detailed descriptions of herps around the area
customer_reviews.text: Excellent guide with detailed descriptions of herps around the area. An essential tool for anyone that loves being outdoors!
customer_reviews.author: Daniel A Garza

customer_reviews.title: Five Stars
customer_reviews.text: Very good pictures to compare what you caught, and good descriptions of the reptiles and amphibians.
customer_reviews.author: Tito Molina

customer_reviews.title: Four Stars
customer_reviews.text: The pictures are good and so are the descriptions. I used it for a biology class.
customer_reviews.author: Skye

customer_reviews.title: Great book
customer_reviews.text: I bought this book for my husband for his birthday. He is a scientist/ecologist/herpetologist, and was so happy to get this book. He very much likes the revised format, no more flipping back and forth, as in the older version. When I gave him the book he disappeared for a few hours contently reading. Excellent source of information. Highly recommend.
customer_reviews.author: tofuhead

customer_reviews.title: Interesting facts about Reptiles and Amphibians
customer_reviews.text: A meaningful addition to our home library. My son loved it while preparing for a competitive event on Herpetology.
customer_reviews.author: PANY

customer_reviews.title: Worthy upgrade to a classic
customer_reviews.text: A worthy upgrade to a classic. Plenty of name changes and WTF, 3 species of Macroclemys?? Plenty of coverage of exotic lizards in Florida and it's got some real well written tidbits of ID. Loved the newly redesigned "pond slider" ID photos with differences in the species plainly marked near the pictures. Belongs in your car next to the snake hook and bags.
customer_reviews.author: Toad S. Hopper

customer_reviews.title: Five Stars
customer_reviews.text: Best and most up to date field guide for North American herps.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: great book to teach kids about our wild neighbors!
customer_reviews.text: Kids love reptiles and amphibians. Parents love educational books that are also fun. We can explore the creatures that live around us, even if we rarely see them. And we DO see them. We saw a box turtle crossing the road the other day. So nice to be able to identify it in this book and teach the 3 & 5 year old boys about turtles.
customer_reviews.author: NS

customer_reviews.title: but it's not the best guide. I'd like to look for some other ...
customer_reviews.text: It does help me with reptile and amphibian identification, but it's not the best guide. I'd like to look for some other guides, but I have not found others on Amazon. I mean, I will keep the guide, but it's just not as good and easy to use as any of my three bird guides and one butterfly guide.
customer_reviews.author: Wendy

customer_reviews.title: Your Reptiles and Amphibians of Eastern/ Central North America shows ...
customer_reviews.text: Your Reptiles and Amphibians of Eastern/ Central North America shows the black tail rattlesnake to be in Texas. I have seen two in Alabama just north west of Montgomery.
customer_reviews.author: mm

customer_reviews.title: This was a gift for my 7 year old granddaughter ...
customer_reviews.text: This was a gift for my 7 year old granddaughter, she has her dad read to her and she studies the charts and photographs.
customer_reviews.author: Bob Paetschow

customer_reviews.title: Field Guide
customer_reviews.text: Got this for my hubby.He loves turtles and nature.Peterson books are great.
customer_reviews.author: n n c

customer_reviews.title: Five Stars
customer_reviews.text: Handy to have around. May folks have been awaiting this update.
customer_reviews.author: Kindle CusRaymond McConnelltomer

customer_reviews.title: Five Stars
customer_reviews.text: Just we needed to get to know our Georgia snakes
customer_reviews.author: froggy

customer_reviews.title: Five Stars
customer_reviews.text: Very handy reference tool. Up to date with regard to taxonomy.
customer_reviews.author: William G. Buchholz

customer_reviews.title: Excellent notations. Includes new species from 2 years ago
customer_reviews.text: Detailed. Excellent notations. Includes new species from 2 years ago.
customer_reviews.author: Rosanna Steffen

customer_reviews.title: Taking Roger Conant off as lead author was cheap. ...
customer_reviews.text: Taking Roger Conant off as lead author was cheap. I am embarrassed for Peterson Field Guides in general and Robert Powell in particular.
customer_reviews.author: GMB

product_meta.title: Peterson Field Guide to Reptiles and Amphibians of Eastern and Central North America, Fourth Edition (Peterson Field Guides)
